summary: HIV-1 is transferred to uninfected cells most efficiently if infected and uninfected cells directly contact each other. such transmission requires successful assembly and release of viral particles from infected (producer) cells followed by their entry into adjoining uninfected (target) cells. cytoskeleton-interacting proteins regulate cortical actin and aid in the recruitment of CD4 and coreceptors to the site of viral attachment and entry. disruption of actin dynamics using drugs has been reported to have only small effects on HIV-1 assembly and release (25, 28, 29), suggesting that these steps are not dependent on the cytoskeleton. however, these analyses do not allow one to make predictions about whether these cytoskeletal structures are important for virus dissemination via cell-cell contacts. phosphatidylinositol 4,5-bisphosphate (PIP2) is essential for Gag targeting to the plasma membrane. ezrin is required for proper microcluster mobility in both T and B cells. kinase ZAP-70 is positioned at the IS by ezrin. previous studies examining ERM proteins in the target cell have documented both positive (8, 49) and negative (50–52; also our unpublished results) roles for these proteins during the early phase of the HIV-1 replication cycle, as well as during the early phase of other viruses (53). here, we focused our investigations on the potential importance of ERM proteins in producer cells by evaluating how these proteins contribute to (or counteract) successful cell-to-cell transmission. reagent was obtained from John Moore and Catherine Spenlehauer
